datafield.subfield: We discuss 6 GHz JVLA observations covering a volume-limited sample of 178 low-redshift ($0.2\lt z\lt 0.3$) optically selected quasi-stellar objects (QSOs). Our 176 radio detections fall into two clear categories: (1) about 20% are radio-loud QSOs (RLQs) with spectral luminosities of ${L}_{6}\gtrsim {10}^{23.2}\,{\rm{W}}\,{\mathrm{Hz}}^{-1}$ that are primarily generated in the active galactic nucleus (AGN) responsible for the excess optical luminosity that defines a bona fide QSO, and (2) the remaining 80% that are radio-quiet QSOs (RQQs) that have ${10}^{21}\lesssim {L}_{6}\lesssim {10}^{23.2}\,{\rm{W}}\,{\mathrm{Hz}}^{-1}$ and radio sizes $\lesssim 10\,\mathrm{kpc}$, and we suggest that the bulk of their radio emission is powered by star formation in their host galaxies. “Radio-silent” QSOs (${L}_{6}\lesssim {10}^{21}\,{\rm{W}}\,{\mathrm{Hz}}^{-1}$) are rare, so most RQQ host galaxies form stars faster than the Milky Way, they are not “red and dead” ellipticals. Earlier radio observations did not have the luminosity sensitivity of ${L}_{6}\lesssim {10}^{21}\,{\rm{W}}\,{\mathrm{Hz}}^{-1}$ that is needed to distinguish between such RLQs and RQQs. Strong, generally double-sided radio emission spanning $\gg 10\,\mathrm{kpc}$ was found to be associated with 13 of the 18 RLQ cores with peak flux densities of ${S}_{{\rm{p}}}\gt 5\,\mathrm{mJy}\,{\mathrm{beam}}^{-1}$ ($\mathrm{log}(L)\gtrsim 24$). The radio luminosity function of optically selected QSOs and the extended radio emission associated with RLQs are both inconsistent with simple “unified” models that invoke relativistic beaming from randomly oriented QSOs to explain the difference between RLQs and RQQs. Some intrinsic property of the AGNs or their host galaxies must also determine whether or not a QSO appears radio-loud.

SDSS colors well outside the stellar locus in the (u-g),(g-r),(r-i) color cube 2002: #apjaa3b6cbib69). SDSS objects were targeted for spectroscopic follow-up by more than one algorithm. To avoid any bias toward QSO candidates favored for spectroscopic confirmation because they were detected by the 1.4 GHz FIRST survey Becker et al : #apjaa3b6cbib4), we considered only those QSOs chosen on the basis of color
At least one broad emission line with \mathrm{FWHM}\,\gt 1000\,\mathrm{km}\,{{\rm{s}}}^{-1} for spectroscopic confirmation of an AGN
{M}_{{\rm{i}}}\lt -23 to exclude Seyfert nuclei and other low-luminosity AGNs

0.2\lt z\lt 0.3. This narrow redshift range minimizes the effects of evolution and the degeneracy between luminosity and redshift. The low maximum redshift z = 0.3 ensures that sensitive VLA observations can detect sources with luminosities only a few times that of the Milky Way, {L}_{6}\sim {10}^{21.3}\,{\rm{W}}\,{\mathrm{Hz}}^{-1}. Combined with the requirement that {M}_{{\rm{i}}}\lt -23, z\lt 0.3 also implies {m}_{{\rm{i}}}\lt 19 after correction for extinction, according to (, 1998: #apjaa3b6cbib74). This is brighter than the SDSS completeness limit for QSO spectroscopy, so our QSO sample is truly volume-limited. Our sample QSOs are labeled in the SDSS quasar catalog with the flag Richards et al : #apjaa3b6cbib69), as the SDSS targeting algorithm happens to be particularly efficient for the identification of low-redshift quasars., 5: #apjaa3b6cfn2

The {\rm{\Omega }}\approx 3.6\,\mathrm{sr} SDSS area bounded by 90^\circ \lt \,{\rm{R}}.{\rm{A}}.\,\lt \,300^\circ, b\gt 30^\circ is large enough to yield a statistically useful number N = 179 of color-selected QSOs in the (, 2010: #apjaa3b6cbib79) quasar catalog of the seventh data release of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) Abazajian et al : #apjaa3b6cbib1). We later found that one QSO, J1107+080, is badly confused by an unrelated strong radio galaxy only 3^{\prime\prime} away in projection but at a much lower redshift (Section, 4: #apjaa3b6cs4). As we cannot obtain useful radio data for J1107+080 and have no reason to believe that J1107+080 is intrinsically different from the other sample QSOs, we excluded it and used only the remaining 178 QSOs in the following analysis
Column (1): Source name, format SDSS JHHMMSS.SS+DDMMSS.S
Column (2): Seconds of right ascension in the VLA position
Column (3): Arcsec of declination in the VLA position
Column (4): Angular separation Δ between the radio and optical positions (arcsec)
Column (6): 6 GHz integrated flux density S (μJy) including any extended structure and its rms error calculated as the quadratic sum of the statistical error and a 3% uncertainty in the calibration
Column (7): 6 GHz peak flux density {S}_{{\rm{p}}} (μJy, beam-1) at 3\buildrel{\prime\prime}\over{.} 5 resolution and its rms error calculated as in column 6
Column (8): Ratio of peak to integrated flux density
Column (9): Log of the 6 GHz spectral luminosity in the source frame (W Hz-1)
Column (10): Apparent i magnitude from the SDSS catalog
Column (12): of radio (6 GHz) to optical (i band) flux density calculated from {S}_{i}={10}^{(9.56-i/2.5)} μJy
